subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: ... Maybe, but how many people will already have been discouraged from using your library just because you didn t give them enough hooks? This has happened to
messageBody:
On 10/31/05, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> David Saff wrote:
>
> > There's a large difference between the wise human mentor, who will
> > occasionally say to even the most inexperienced mentee "Yes, you're
> > right, I hadn't thought of that", and a released library, in which the
> > answer is ordained before the question is asked. Perhaps a humble
> > library writer might look for ways to have that answer not always be
> "No"?
>
> If you're unsure of what to do when writing a library, it's better to do
> nothing. When in doubt, leave it out. You can always put it in again
> later,


Maybe, but how many people will already have been discouraged from using
your library just because you didn't give them enough hooks?

This has happened to me *many* times, both as a library author and as a
library user. And more often than not, I have sworn after the author of a
library because they made a method private instead of protected (worst
offender: MIDP1, where you don't even have the option of changing the
code).


Do as little as you can get away with. This principle makes both the library
> developers' and the users'
> lives easier. Options are not free.


We'll just agree to disagree. I, for one, am quite happy to see that JUnit4
will come with a reasonable amount of protected methods "for future
experimentations".


It's not as if the library is fixed in stone and nothing can ever be
> added to it.


Actually, most of the time, it is. I mentioned MIDP1 above, but even if you
are thinking of open-source libraries, modifying the source means forking
the code most of the time, with all the maintenance nightmare that ensue.


If someone thinks of something you hadn't thought of, add
> it. But don't add just because you think someone somewhere someday
> might perhaps need it, even though you can't quite see how.


You seem to be living in a world where every author of any imaginable
library is magically available and willing to make the changes you need when
you ask for them right away.

My experience is the complete opposite of that.

--
Cédric
